intro: Amsinckia intermedia var. eastwoodiae, commonly known as the Eastwood's hairy goldenweed, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States. It belongs to the family Asteraceae and is characterized by its yellow, daisy-like flowers and hairy, lance-shaped leaves. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky soils and is often found in desert and semi-desert environments. It produces small, oval seeds that are dispersed by wind, contributing to its ability to colonize arid landscapes. This variety is distinguished by its unique leaf morphology and floral structure compared to other members of the species.
